Mahagathbandhan.description: NEW DELHI: Taking a swipe at the grand alliance of opposition parties, finance minister Arun Jaitley on Friday said the 'mahagathbandhan' is a 'non-bandhan', political circus and a recipe for chaos. Several political parties, mostly traditional BJP opponents, have come together to take on the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) in the ensuing general elections beginning April 11. In a blog post, Jaitley said that over the last several months, India was "exhausted" with the talk of a 'Mahagathbandhan'. The rationale, he said, was that Prime Minister Narendra Modi and the BJP were very strong and could not be challenged by individual party. Stressing that Indians judge politicians by their merit and capacity and no longer by any traditional loyalty, he said: "We were promised a 'coalition of rivals' because India had to be saved. We were promised a common minimum agenda. Each leader amongst the aspirant Prime Ministers wanted to become a 'sutradhar' (anchor) of the alliance. He/she would periodically organise shows in his/her State and invite the entire bandwagon." In opposition camp, Jaitley said there is a tussle for leadership as already multiple candidates have made their desire clear to take over the mantle of the leadership. According to him, each one of them is interested to see the strength of the other party's contender depleting and also have high hopes in a chaotic and highly hung Parliament. "He/ she believes that only in a chaotic situation he/she has a chance," said Jaitley, who is heading the BJP's publicity division of the seven-phase Lok Sabha elections. The past track record of such governments in terms of policy, longevity and growth has to be borne in mind, he said adding their track record of corruption is equally well-known. Jaitley further said it is only because of the size of the BJP and clarity on leadership in the last coalition that a successful government was run under Prime Minister Modi. "Today you have no 'gathbandhan' let alone 'mahagathbandhan'. It is a 'non-bandhan'. You have no leader, no programme, no meeting of minds. "Stability, which is paramount, is a major casualty. The only thing in common is negative agenda 'remove one man'. It is a recipe for chaos," he said in the blog titled 'A Political Circus Called 'Mahagathbandhan'. The nominations for the first two phases of polling are over and those for the third phase are about to happen. The results will be announced on May 23. PM Modi.description: JEYPORE: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Friday said his government had taken measures to set up a 'chowkidar' in space and asked people to vote for a government that can take concrete decisions and not just raise slogans. Launching his campaign in eastern India with a rally in Jeypore area of Odisha's Koraput district, the prime minister said the NDA government wouldn't have been able to do any development work in the country without the support of the people. He sought blessings from his supporters for the 2019 Lok Sabha elections and asserted that the NDA government has left no stone unturned to bring about development in the state. Land, air or space, we had courage to do surgical strikes: PM Modi"The NDA government has been working hard to develop road and rail infrastructure in the state. There is no dearth of funds when it comes to development work in the country. "In the last five years, the government has been able to build homes for eight lakh families, light up 3,000 houses and provide gas connections to 40 lakh homes," Modi stated. Referring to Mission Shakti, when India demonstrated anti-satellite (ASAT) missile capability by shooting down a live satellite, he said the government has taken measures to set up a 'chowkidar' (watchman) in space. He came down heavily on opposition parties who he said "belittled" the space achievement. "Those that are criticising the anti-satellite technology will be given a befitting reply in the elections," he claimed, urging people to vote for a government that can take concrete decisions, not the one that only raises slogans. Lucknow: Drive against strays fails to p.description: LUCKNOW: Despite a high court order to make Cantonment roads free of stray cattle by June 30, the Lucknow Cantonment Board (LCB) has caught only 40% of the stray animals so far. On May 28, the high court had directed the Lucknow Municipal Corporation and Cantonment Board to remove stray cattle and garbage piles from Cantonment. On June 1, the LCB had launched a drive to catch stray animals in the civil areas, particularly Sadar and Topkhana Bazaar. But so far, only 120 stray bulls and cows out of estimated 300 have been caught. Sadar Bazaar residents say that stray cattle continue to be a menace. They cause traffic jams and pose threat to commuters and pedestrians, especially elderly and children. Stray cows can be seen in the main Sadar market in the morning. Civic authorities promises us that the menace would end whenever they launch such drives but nothing happens," said Sunil Kumar, a resident. Besides the animals also cause damage to the gardens and green areas. They also raised complaints over the issue of cattle dung on roads and outside their homes, but to no avail. Amit Mishra, CEO of Lucknow Cantonment Board, said, "We have sent 83 stray animals to Kanha Upvan while the rest will be shifted to a cow shelter in Memaura soon." Yogi Adityanath rushes to Delhi ahead of.description: LUCKNOW: Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath on Tuesday cancelled all his official engagements and rushed to Delhi to discuss expansion of the state cabinet and strategy for the 11 byelections in the state. Even the cabinet meeting, which took a series of important decisions, was advanced for about an hour so that the CM could leave for Delhi. Officials said Yogi, along with BJP general secretary for UP Sunil Bansal, visited Delhi to greet the new working president of the party JP Nadda and attend a dinner hosted by the party's national organising secretary Ram Lal. Sources said discussions on the new BJP state president Mahendra Pandey's elevation as a cabinet minister in the Modi government was also discussed. The CM had a series of engagements for most of the day and an official programme of distribution of laptops to revenue officials here on Tuesday. Ordinance bars anti-national activity in.description: LUCKNOW: Private universities in UP will have to give an undertaking at the time of getting approvals that it will “not be involved in any anti-national activity, allow such activity within its premises or let its name be used for any such activity. Any such act would be construed as violation of the rules of establishment and the government can take action.” The existing 27 private universities in the state have been given a year to promulgate rules according to the Uttar Pradesh Private University Ordinance, 2019, which was passed by the state Cabinet on Tuesday. The ordinance will now be presented in the Assembly in the session beginning from July 18. The ordinance makes provisions for “inclusion of a sense of national integration, secularism, social equality and international harmony in the objectives of the universities.” Among its other clauses, the ordinance states that “universities will not be allowed to bestow an honorary degree without prior approval of the state government. 75% of teaching staff will be regular appointmentsThe appointment of vice-chancellor can also be done by the chancellor only after consultation with the governing body.” It has been proposed in the ordinance that “land for the university cannot be sold, transferred or leased though it can be mortgaged to a bank or financial institution for establishment of the university.” The ordinance further states that a “minimum of 75% teaching staff have to be regular appointments. A common academic calendar will be specified under which there will be common dates for conducting of exams and declaration of results.” Provision has been made in the ordinance to ensure that fee structures are placed in the public domain. Also, “universities will have to reserve 10% seats for students from the economically backward category. Such students will pay only 50% of the normal fee”. According to the ordinance, the UP State Higher Education Council will now be the nodal agency that will oversee compliance of the ordinance and rules. It empowers the council to file reports with the government for action if it is unable to get information from any private university within a specified period of time. The council, as per the ordinance, will “inspect a university at least once a year to monitor the quality of education and its compliance with rules, and submit an annual report on its working. If any violation comes to light, the state government will issue appropriate instruction which will be mandatory for the university to follow.” The government, the ordinance said, is also “empowered to revoke recognition to a university if charges of cheating, corruption or misuse of funds against it are proven. The council can order an investigation into such charges. After the university is given a chance to defend itself, the government will be authorised to dissolve the university through a notification.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

UP government moots slashing delay in re.description: LUCKNOW: Flooded by complaints of repeated and prolonged power outages amidst searing summers, the state government is planning to slash the time limit for replacement of burnt transformers from 48 hours to 24 hours in rural areas and from 24 hours to 12 hours in urban areas. The government has also decided to come up with a new policy in which every transformer would be metered. The decisions were taken at a high level meeting called by energy minister Shrikant Sharma. “Now most villages have better link roads and therefore time limit for replacing damaged transformers should come down significantly,” Sharma told TOI. “Transformers are no more transported in bullock carts in rural areas. They are instead moved in mechanized trolleys and tractors. Therefore, there is ample scope for improvement, especially in rural areas,” he said. The officials have also been asked to step up efforts to complete the separation of agriculture and domestic feeders by June-end. The decision is seen as a UPPCL move to reduce overloading of transmission and distribution lines. UPPCL sources said, separation of 1,800 feeders in Paschimanchal and Dakshinanchal has been completed, but work is moving at a snail’s pace in Madhyanchal and Paschimanchal. The department also decided to convert all un-metered rural consumers into metered ones by the year-end. The un-metered consumers are mainly in rural areas and account for 19% of total electricity consumption. Sharma said that metering would ensure more revenue which would be used for better facilities. The department has also proposed that the monthly charge of un-metered consumers be increased from Rs 400 to Rs 500. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Teenager tries to kill self over 'poor m.description: LUCKNOW: A 17-year-old girl tried to commit suicide on Tuesday because she did not get admission in the college of her choice after class XII. The girl jumped in front of a train in Hasanganj and was badly injured. However, a team of police took the girl to trauma centre where she was treated. In a letter, the girl, Khushi, wrote, "Due to poor grades, I did not get admission due to which I am not able to complete my studies." She also regretted that she "was a girl". If she was a boy, she wrote, she would have survived because a boy can survive even without studying. Her father Mannapal is a security guard and she has a 15-year-old brother. "I don't understand why she has taken this step. God has saved her," he said. Hasanganj SHO Dhirendra Pratap Kushwaha said the case is under government railway police. Mayawati to reveal reason for ending pac.description: LUCKNOW: BSP chief Mayawati is scheduled to address an all-India meeting of her party in Lucknow on June 23 where, among issues related to the upcoming by-elections in UP, she is expected to speak about her decision to sever her alliance with Samajwadi Party. Mayawati, who had been in Delhi after the declaration of the Lok Sabha elections in which her party won 10 seats in UP, returned to Lucknow on Tuesday. In a meeting of party workers held on June 3, Mayawati had sprung a major surprise by announcing the end of alliance with SP and her decision to contest by-elections in UP. “While nobody will question her, there were many in the party who did not understand her decision to cut off the alliance with SP. She had said that it was because the SP had failed to transfer its votes to BSP, leading to a not so impressive performance by the alliance, and the party now needs a way forward,” said a BSP functionary. AP BJP List 2019.description: NEW DELHI: The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), on Thursday, announced its first candidate list for the Lok Sabha elections 2019 that includes 184 candidates. The party has named two candidates from Andhra Pradesh in the first list. Kanna Lakshminarayana will contest from Narasaraopet Lok Sabha constituency while D Purandeshwari will contest from the Visakhapatnam seat. Andhra Pradesh will go to polls in a single phase on April 11. BJP's Lok Sabha first full list The Lok Sabha elections will be held in seven phases from April 11 to May 19, 2019. The counting of the votes has been scheduled for May 23. The first phase will be held on April 11, second on April 18, third on April 23 and fourth on April 29, fifth on May 6, sixth on May 12 and seventh phase on May 19. Prime Minister Narendra Modi will contest from Varanasi constituency, while BJP president Amit Shah will fight from Gandhinagar in place of L K Advani. As many as 90 crore electors, including 1.59 crore new voters aged 18-19 years, are registered to vote in the upcoming general election. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Gharial hatchlings spring hope in Katarn.description: LUCKNOW: Their numbers were going down steadily at the Katarniaghat Wildlife Sanctuary till late but in a pleasant surprise for wildlife conservationists, over 150 gharial hatchlings swam into the river Girwa on Wednesday morning. An endangered species endemic to India, especially to the northern region, the number of gharials at the wildlife sanctuary have seen an over 50% rise in population. From mere 15 gharial nests in the river Girwa, wildlife conservationists at the sanctuary counted 32 nests this year. “As many as 852 hatchlings came out of eggshells in these 32 nests and went into the river. We managed to save 160 hatchlings, and will protect their life so that their population can be increased further,” said Dudhwa Tiger reserve field director Ramesh Pandey. The Katarniaghat wildlife sanctuary falls under Dudhwa tiger reserve. “In 2005, there were just five gharial nests. After conservation, their count went up to 30-40 in next decade. But last year, the number went down to 15,” he added. The conservationists then noticed that the sandbars used by the fish-eating narrow snout gharials were changing form significantly. This was because of over growth of tall grass, change in nature of sandbar’s slopes when they got submerged in water and the presence of predators like dogs and vultures. “We systematically eliminated all of these factors, held vigils in teams and protected the eggs that the gharials hide in sandpits and the hatchlings from predators,” said Pandey. Adding to the number of the species, conservationists have re-started the process of keeping back some hatchlings to help in population growth. “The 160 hatchlings we have kept with us, will be nurtured to attain strength and will be reintroduced into the river in winters so that chances of their survival improve and the survival rate is higher than when they are smaller and are in the river,” said Pandey. Satta King 2019.description: NEW DELHI: Satta Matka is a form of gambling or lottery that had originated before the Independence of India.Originally, the game of Matka gambling involved betting on the opening and closing rates of cotton as transmitted to the Bombay Cotton Exchange from the New York Cotton Exchange, via teleprinters.The modern-day Matka gambling/ Satta King is based on random number selection and betting. The players participating in the Satta Matka game/ gambling are required to choose the right number for winning the game. The player who wins the game becomes Satta King and is rewarded financially. Two of the most famous Matka games are - Kalyan and Worli. The Kalyan Matka gambling was started by Kalyanji Bhagat, a farmer from Gujarat, in 1962 and it ran for all days of the week. Another Matka gambling, New Worli Matka, was started by the Rattan Khatri in 1964 with slight modifications to the rules of the game. Khatri’s Matka ran only five days a week, from Monday to Friday.The modern Matka business is centred around Maharashtra.Some of the terms used in the game and their meaning is given below:    Term Meaning   Matka Matka means earthen pot that were used to draw numbers   Single Any digit between 0 and 9   Jodi/Pair Any pair of two digits between 00 and 99    Patti/Panna Three digit number    Open result / close result Outcome of matka betting   Berij Berij is last digit of jodi's/pair's sum The Google 2018 trends data shows that 'satta' and 'matka' were the top searched words in the Madhya Pradesh state in the year 2018. As per the Google data, 'satta' was the 4th most searched word with a score of 36 and 'matka' came 6th with a score of 23.Any form of Satta Matka gambling is illegal in India.Disclaimer: This content is for reference purpose only and The Times of India claims no ownership of this content. The Times of India does not support or promote piracy in any manner.Download The Times of India News App for Latest India News.

Lok Sabha Elections in Tamil Nadu.description: NEW DELHI: Tamil Nadu goes to polls in the second phase of the seven-phase elections. Elections to 39 parliamentary seats will take place on April 18 in a single-phase polling. Lok Sabha elections 2019: Get all live updatesTOP CONTENDERSThe four-cornered contest features AIADMK-led National Democratic Alliance (NDA), its chief rival DMK-led Secular Progressive Alliance (SPA), actor Kamal Haasan's Makkal Needhi Maiam and TTV Dhinakaran's Amma Makkal Munnetra Kazhagam (AMMK). This time the elections are taking place sans the Dravidian stalwarts M Karunanidhi and J Jayalalithaa. AIADMK chief Jayalalithaa passed away in December 2016 while Karunanidhi died in August 2018. While the DMK is contesting on 20 seats, the Congress is fighting elections on 9 seats in Tamil Nadu. In the AIADMK-BJP alliance, the national party will be contesting from five seats in the state while the PMK will be contesting from seven. Tamil Nadu Lok Sabha elections: Get all live updatesHOW MANY SEATS?Tamil Nadu has 39 Lok Sabha seats and one in neighbouring Puducherry. Lucknow civic body fires, hires & fires.description: LUCKNOW: The Lucknow Municipal Corporation (LMC) has terminated the contracts of three private agencies that were hired despite being blacklisted for shoddy performance in the past, but it is yet to initiate action against its own officials who engaged them a second time. According to LMC records, the original contracts of these agencies were revoked and they were blacklisted in December 2018 for slacking off on garbage collection, cleaning drains and sweeping roads. However, they were hired once more in March this year by the corporation’s zonal officials. The anomalies came to light recently when municipal commissioner Indramani Tripathi was reviewing complaint registers. Residents of Raqabganj and Aashiana had voiced maximum grievances. On enquiry, Tripathi found that the three agencies at fault had earlier held contracts of Campbell Road, Yahiyaganj and Jankipuram extension. They were hired again by LMC zonal offices for Raqabganj, Aashiana and Alambagh. Tripathi said he had cancelled the contracts once more and ordered a probe into the role of zonal officials in hiring blacklisted agencies. New agencies have now been entrusted with cleanliness work in the affected areas, he added. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Snatch gangs stalk morning walkers in Lu.description: LUCKNOW: If you’re a woman who loves to flaunt her gold trinkets or a man with a fat wallet, it is time to exercise extra caution. TimesViewFrequent incidents of chain and purse snatchings in the heart of the city mean there is no fear law among petty criminals . In such a scenario, CCTV cameras and quick response by police can act as deterrents. In case of arrest, evidence in the form of footage will help speed up investigation. Severe punishment should follow, especially for repeat offenders.A police dossier has listed 255 cases of chain and cash snatching in the city since January, which effectively means one person is being targeted every 15 hours. Worse, very few of the these cases have been cracked till date in the absence of effective electronic surveillance. Indiranagar and Gomtinagar top the list of unsafe neighbourhoods with a total of 49 cases followed by Aliganj with 11. The victims were mostly morning walkers, besides working women returning home late from office. In some cases, the accused used firearms to rob their victims of valuables. On May 29, two bikers tried to rob Urmila Devi of her gold chain at gunpoint in B Block, Indiranagar. She managed to retain half of the chain. Shikha Tiwari of Mahanagar recalled the horror of June 3 when two men flashed a pistol and snatched her gold chain in broad daylight. There were no patrol teams or CCTV cameras to nail them, Tiwari said. On June 8, Rekha Shah was robbed of her gold chain right in front of a police outpost in Talkatora. It was early morning. Her husband was teaching her how to ride a scooter. There were no policemen who could come to their rescue, she recalled. Not just women, snatch gangs have targeted men too in the recent past. On June 7, Ayush Jaiswal was robbed of his wallet by two men on a bike near Bhoothnath market. He says police have done precious little to identify the culprits, let alone arrest them. Sangeeta Agarwal of Mahanagar is still afraid to go out alone. On June 11, two men on a bike snatched her chain near Gole market when she was out to buy milk. “I have stopped venturing out alone since that day. Police rarely patrol the city and CCTV cameras are absent. The city has become unsafe,” she said. Ayushi Garg of Vibhuti Khand, who was robbed near Kathauta Crossing in May, said Lucknow police lack a dedicated mechanism to curb snatching. “Last year, my friend was targeted at Husadiya Crossing while my aunt was robbed near Viram Khand crossing in 2017. Police are yet to crack those cases or take concrete measures to prevent rerun,” she said. SSP Kalanidhi Naithani denied allegations that police were not doing enough to curb bike gangs that target unsuspecting victims and speed away. “We have identified vulnerable areas. These will now be geo-tagged to facilitate regular patrolling by the UP 100 fleet, besides district police,” he said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Arvind Kejriwal.description: VISAKHAPATNAM: Delhi chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Monday said that Congress President Rahul Gandhi has refused to forge an alliance with the AAP for the Lok Sabha polls in the national capital. Full coverage: Lok Sabha electionsTalking to reporters at the airport here, the AAP leader said he had met Gandhi recently and the Congress leader had refused to “join hands with the AAP”. Asked about Congress' Delhi unit president Sheila Dikshit's remarks that Kejriwal never approached her for an alliance, the chief minister said, “We have met Rahul Gandhi. Dikshit is not that important leader.” Kejriwal has been urging the Congress to stitch an alliance in Delhi for the Lok Sabha polls to keep the BJP away from power. Leaders in the Delhi unit of the Congress were divided over the issue of alliance with Dikshit and her three working presidents opposing it, party sources had said. A top source in the party had recently said that chances of alliance were "slim" considering its long term repercussions in Delhi. "The biggest question is how will Congress face the AAP in Assembly elections due in 2020 after the tie up. Also, the party does not gain much politically as it is being offered only 2-3 seats by Kejriwal," the source had said. Congress had drawn a blank in the 2014 parliamentary elections in Delhi. The talk of alliance was fuelled by the fact that the Congress and AAP had jointly polled more votes than the BJP that had walked away with all the seven seats in the national capital. Delhi has 7 Lok Sabha seats and it will go to polls on May 12. Now, Uttar Pradesh press releases will b.description: LUCKNOW: In a bid to promote Sanskrit, the Uttar Pradesh government will now issue press releases in Sanskrit along with Hindi, English and Urdu, an official said on Tuesday. The first press note in Sanskrit was issued by the state government’s information department on Monday. Information department officials said the important speeches of CM Yogi Adityanath and government information will be released also in Sanskrit, along with Hindi, English and Urdu. “This is the first time that such a step is being taken. The speech of CM delivered at a recent Niti Aayog meeting was released in Sanskrit and was well received. Now we plan to expand it further”. During a function on Monday, Adityanath had said that Sanskrit was in the DNA of the country. “Sanskrit is in the DNA of India, it is now limited to the work of priests,” he had said. Incidentally, there are 25 periodicals in Uttar Pradesh which are printed in Sanskrit but none of them is a daily. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Yoga studies, a passport to plum jobs ab.description: LUCKNOW: A postgraduate degree in yoga helped Amit Khanna (35) land the prestigious job of “teaching Indian culture” at the Consulate General of India in Houston, US. And, he is not alone. Many of his peers have found lucrative assignments abroad, thanks to their exceptional qualification. At a time seats in other humanities courses are lying vacant at Lucknow University, the number of applications for various degree and certificate courses in yoga have increased five times in four years. The varsity runs three courses — a PG degree, a PG diploma and a certificate — with a total 140 seats. Till 2014, most seats remained empty. Today, they receive 500-600 applications a year. Many alumni are now yoga instructors not just in the US, but in the UK, rest of Europe, Australia, in the Gulf, Thailand and China, among others. Reena Keshari, an LU alumna who now teaches yoga in Muscat, Oman, decoded the popularity of the course. Yoga drills will be held at several places across the city on Friday Freelancing, teaching other career avenuesEarlier, a certificate or degree in yoga meant a job in a school or at the local gym. But now, it can be your passport to success abroad. Many Indian-origin instructors have started their own yoga centres in Oman,” said Reena, who makes a decent Rs 8 lakh annually. Amit who opted for a masters in naturopathy was compelled to study yoga because the PG course offered a combination of both subjects. He soon realised how and why yoga was a better career option for him. He joined a health project at KGMU before being selected for his current job. “The course in yoga provided a deep insight of Indian culture, which gave me an edge during the consulate interview. Indian yoga instructors in the US are making up to $150 dollars a day by teaching at various institutes or by freelancing,” he said. Akash Mishra is pursuing his MA in yoga. “I was always intrigued by asanas. What our LU alumni have achieved helped me convince my parents to allow me to take up the course,” he said. Arti Sharma, another student, said yoga was not physical exercise, but a philosophy that captivates people across the globe. “I have applied for jobs at several institutions abroad. I hope to spread yogic values far and wide.” Satyendra Mishra, a faculty member at the Institute of Human Consciousness and Yogic Sciences, LU, said besides jobs as trainers and teachers in India and abroad, yoga studies also offered career opportunities in research and digital media. Meanwhile, To mark International Day of Yoga, City Montessori School, Rajajipuram Campus I, will host an inter-school meet from 6am on Friday at its Kanpur Road auditorium Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Lucknow development authority offer for.description: LUCKNOW: Lucknow Development Authority (LDA) has decided to introduce a one-time settlement (OTS) scheme for defaulters to pay the remaining amount for apartments they have bought from the authority. The scheme will give the defaulters a discount of 10% and all the fine on the pending amount will be waived. According to LDA officials, there are more than 26,000 defaulters on the list. These defaulters have not paid their EMI for months. LDA finance controller Rajeev Kumar Singh said, “The OTS will be implemented after the government’s approval. The authority could gain around Rs 75 crore pending for long.” Defaulters can pay online or at LDA office. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Yogi Adityanath to officials: Will not t.description: LUCKNOW: Uttar Pradesh has adopted zero tolerance policy on crime against minorities, minors, women and Dalits, said chief minister Yogi Adityanath at a review meeting on law and order situation in the state. “Strict action will be taken against those involved in any such crime,” said Yogi. In the second such meeting in a week, the chief minister reviewed the performance and achievements of the state home department, attended by chief secretary Anoop Chand Pandey, principal secretary (home) Arvind Kumar, DGP OP Singh and other heads of police organisations. Non-performers should be weeded out of the department through compulsory retirement in order to make the functioning of the police more target-oriented and sensitive to people, said Yogi. Earlier this week, in a hurriedly called meeting in the wake of a spate of crime against women and minors that led to a national outrage, the CM had sent out a warning to district magistrates and superintendents of police that they would be held directly responsible for crime in their districts. Yogi said crime control figures and statistics should be matched with public perception. “Unless the common man feels safe and satisfied, so-called decline in crime figures become meaningless,” he said. He said that officers should be asked to spend maximum time on the field and criminals should fear the state and police authorities. A special drive for booking of elusive and “wanted” criminals should be initiated, he added. On pending cases of corruption in which the EOW, vigilance and CID have sought the state government’s sanction, the chief minister said that the state would expedite the process of providing sanction. The chief minister reminded the officers of the arrest of three private secretaries of ministers on corruption charges. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

India Pakistan news.description: NEW DELHI/ISLAMABAD: India dismissed on Thursday as "fake news" the suggestion in Pak media that it was looking to resume talks with the hostile neighbour and asserted that there was no dilution of its position that Islamabad needed to take verifiable and irreversible action against terrorism for the dialogue to resume. Responding to Pakistan PM Imran Khan's congratulatory letter after he assumed office for the second time, PM Narendra Modi wrote back on June 12 expressing India's desire to have normal and cooperative relations with all its neighbours, including Pakistan, while stressing that "for this, it is important to build an environment of trust, free of terror, violence and hostility". Foreign minister S Jaishankar also wrote to his Pakistani counterpart S M Qureshi, again only in response to the latter's congratulatory letter, emphasising the need for an atmosphere "free from the shadow of terror and violence". The emphasis on the need for Pakistan to rein in terror as a pre-condition for re-engagement was in keeping with the stand which saw Modi refrain from engaging with Imran Khan at the just-concluded SCO summit in Kyrgyzstan. Yet, the Pakistani media chose to interpret the contents of the letters of Modi and Jaishankar as reflecting India's desire to re-engage. The foreign ministry in Delhi quickly scotched the suggestion. "There was complete distortion and an attempt to peddle fake news (in the way it was reported). The letters only reiterated India's old position that it wants normal and cooperative relations with all countries in South Asia and that it was important to create an environment free of terror and violence for it. There was no mention of any sort of dialogue with Pakistan," said MEA spokesperson Raveesh Kumar, adding that India will not be fooled by any cosmetic action against terror by Islamabad. Emphasising that both the letters were written in as per the "established diplomatic practice", Kumar said: "In their messages, they have highlighted that India seeks normal and cooperative relations with all neighbours, including Pakistan." In his letter, Modi had said that India remained committed to operationalising early an "all-year-round" Kartarpur corridor. Touching upon it, Kumar said India had already held three technical-level discussions with Pakistan and was currently awaiting clarification from Islamabad over a few issues it had raised. Puzzlingly, later in the evening, Pakistan's foreign ministry, which had kept quiet through the day, also sought to play down the speculation about the import of the letters. While responding to a question, the spokesperson said, "It was an established practice for the leadership to congratulate new office holders and for them to respond." "Pakistan's position on the way forward in relations with India was clear and well-known and did not require repetition," said the spokesperson, adding that the "vision of peace, progress and prosperity of South Asia could be advanced by peacefully resolving all outstanding disputes, including Jammu & Kashmir, and moving away from dynamic of confrontation to cooperation". Earlier in the day, sources in the Pakistan foreign office had said that Modi and Jaishankar had responded positively to recent letters from their Pakistani counterparts by conveying New Delhi's desire to engage with all countries, including Pakistan, for elimination of terrorism and prosperity of the region. "India has always prioritised peace and human development, and sought to maintain cordial relations with all regional powers," Modi and Jaishankar maintained, according to FO sources. Both leaders, according to FO sources, called for special attention on elimination of terrorism in the region and said the issue must be a core focus in all future talks. They have also appreciated sentiments from Pakistan in their letters, the FO sources added. Modi's letter was in response to a congratulatory letter from Khan in which he had underscored Pakistan's vision of working for "durable peace and stability in South Asia with peaceful resolution of all outstanding disputes, including J&K". Satta Market.description: BHOPAL: This assembly  is turning out to be a nail-biter. The Bhopal satta bazaar that gave BJP a good chance three weeks ago is suddenly abuzz about Congress’ prospects. As per the bookies, till about a month ago, if a person placed a bet of Rs 10,000 on BJP, he would get Rs 11,000 if the party returned to power. And anyone who bet Rs 4,400 on Congress would get Rs 10,000 if the opposition wins. This week, bookies say, they are taking bets on number of seats and not on who would form the government. “In case no party gets absolute majority, or if the scoreline is too close,” explained a bookie. “We do not want to say which party will form the government. The bets are open. The satta market is running good this poll season, as it is a thrilling contest,” he added. Bookies told TOI that satta trends may not reflect the actual situation on the ground, but the market is accepting bets on 116-plus seats for Congress and 102 or more for ruling BJP. “Anyone who bets successfully on BJP or Congress will double his money,” a bookie said, adding that this trend may change just as suddenly in the next few days as campaigning gets more intense. The same bookie had told TOI around a month ago that rates may vary once candidates are finalised by the parties, “but we expect the trend to remain the same”. The satta market runs into crores in every election. Bets are placed not just over phone, but also on websites and apps, leaving almost no room for police to track down bookies and those placing bets. Probably, this is why no gang has been busted in the state so far for running an election betting racket. At least two cases of betting are registered daily in Bhopal, but the people pulling the strings of the racket in poll season are yet to be caught. Police officers say it is getting increasingly difficult to nab such gangs because they are constantly on the move. “Online betting can be operated even from a moving car, a café or any public place anywhere in the country. Those running the betting in Bhopal may be sitting anywhere on the globe,” said an officer. SP-south Rahul Kumar Lodha said a special campaign is being run against criminals involved in gambling and betting ahead of elections. “These criminals are made to sign bonds to prevent them from committing such crimes in the future. Raids are being conducted on specific tips. A list of habitual offenders is being prepared by police stations to curb such illegal activities,” he said. ASP-crime Rashmi Mishra said the crime branch has activated its network of informers prior to elections to keep an eye on betting. “It is difficult to crack online betting and gambling rackets, but police take action against criminals on specific inputs. For instance, we were tipped off on Monday night about a betting den in Kolar. It was raided but no such activity was found,” Mishra said, adding that the cyber cell is constantly on the lookout for websites and mobile apps used by betting rackets. Asana classes at home, tailor-made just.description: LUCKNOW: At the crack of dawn, Linki Agarwal grabs her yoga mat and walks up to her terrace where her private yoga instructor waits to guide her on asanas for mental and physical well-being. The homoeopath practitioner prefers the quietude of home to begin a healthy day. There are many like her who find yoga on doorstep a more convenient option than stepping out to attend classes. The trend has over the past four years gained momentum in Lucknow, where busy life often pushes the need to exercise to the back seat. The concept is win-win for both teacher and student, as the demand for home tutoring is helping instructors earn handsome remuneration every month. “The fee usually ranges from Rs 3,000 to Rs 10,000 a month, depending on the needs of an individual student. Many yoga teachers who wish to stay in the city are paying home visits to top up their earnings,” said Dev, an instructor in Gomtinagar. Erika Malhotra, 51, said she began taking yoga lessons at home in 2017 after her husband’s start-up business prompted him to make frequent work trips. “I have had weight issues, but the summer heat and humidity acted as deterrents whenever I decided on a disciplined lifestyle, complete with regular exercise. A team of yoga experts came to my rescue. These instructors are a call away and offer customised asana modules,” Malhotra said. Puja Vaid, the owner of a city café, is a veteran. She has been taking yoga classes at home for 15 years and says the ease of accessibility to these lessons has made all the difference. “When you are a working mom, time is never a luxury. You hardly get the time to go out and train for personal well-being. Home yoga instructors help reduce your stress level because you have their undivided attention,” she added. Agreed Mohit Singh, a yoga instructor in Mahanagar. “At any yoga institute, a typical class has 20-30 people. It is difficult to give special attention to each individual. Hence, home classes are better. Another trend that has emerged in recent years is DIY (do it yourself) yoga, where people watch and learn asanas from YouTube videos,” said Singh. UP among 9 states picked for World Bank.description: LUCKNOW: Joining India’s fight against tuberculosis — a disease that kills over two lakh people in the country annually — the World Bank has decided to invest USD 400 million in nine states, including Uttar Pradesh. Each state will get delivery-based incentives, which means the financial support will be based on performance against pre-decided indicators such as engagement of private sector and achievement against targets such as nutritional support. “The project aims to improve coverage and quality of tuberculosis control interventions in private and public sectors in targeted states,” read the World Bank policy document in this regard. Besides being a killer, TB affects the quality of life of a patient and his/her family, hampers productivity and is known to retard economic development. Around 30% of all TB cases in the world are reported from India and UP accounts for one-fifth of the country’s burden. The Union government has pledged to eradicate TB by 2025, which is five years ahead of the deadline set by WHO. A meeting of stakeholders was held in Delhi earlier this week. “There were discussions on state-level action plans. We will submit ours soon,” said Dr Santosh Gupta, state TB officer. Wells dry up in scorched Bundelkhand , r.description: BANDA/MAHOBA: It was still morning in Banda, yet the heat was oppressive and sweltering, but it made little difference to almost 100 residents of Panghara village who had blocked the highway between Banda and Naraini on June 15. The protesters were all scheduled caste, demanding action against their gram pradhan for providing water supply only to the village area inhabited by upper castes and not giving them any. “We are forced to walk to the handpump across our village, crossing a highway for it. When we cannot go to fill water, our children do. It is highly dangerous for them. The pradhan has diverted all the water to the area where upper caste people live. We are unable to do daily wage work because we have to get water,” said Savitri, a resident. Uttar Pradesh’s Bundelkhand district, one of the most backward in country, has a perennial problem of water scarcity, but the situation is worse this year. In 2018, the region saw rainfall deficiency ranging from 8% to 56%. This year, with monsoon already delayed, the rainfall deficiency between June 1 and June 18 is already being pegged from 26% to 84%. Ponds and wells have dried up and locals have to walk an hour to fetch water. The livestock is worst affected as carcasses are seen lining roads and lying scattered in fields. In the absence of jobs, failing agriculture and water shortage, most people have left for cities for temporary employment and will return to sow their fields when monsoon arrives. In Dhikwaha village of Mahoba district, 18-20 tubewells have gone dry. Princy Yadav (14) tells she has to walk an hour to the only tubewell outside the village to get water. “Around 125 people from our village have gone to cities because there is neither water nor any work here. The women of the households go to fetch water in the morning, and in the evening, it’s the turn of children after they return from school,” she says. It takes 30 minutes to reach the tubewell, but well over two hours are actually spent in returning with water because there is a long queue at the tubewell. “There are frequent fights, as the tubewell often runs out of water and so all the people want to fill their vessels first,” she said. In Dhoraiyan, residents say that 15 families left the village with the onset of summer and will return only after first monsoon rain. “Monsoon had failed last year,” says Pushpa, a resident. “It is delayed this time also because of which agriculture has been seriously affected. The fields are dry and there is no fodder for cattle. The wells and tubewells dried up months back. The government doesn’t send any water tankers,” she added. Mahoba recorded a rainfall deficit of 56% in 2018 where Banda was 8% rain deficient. This year, the pre-monsoon deficit is already 29% and 84%, respectively, with no rains yet to recharge wells and village ponds. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Unique 'bhoosa bank' from fodder donated.description: LUCKNOW: Unnao is set to create a record of sorts with 100 gaushalas coming up in the district in just 90 days and, also, a unique "bhoosa bank" (fodder bank) to feed cattle. Vetenarians will be connected through whatsapp groups for minute-to-minute monitoring of hapless cattle abandoned by farmers and kept in these "gaushalas." The project has been completed by the MNREGA and gram panchayat funds. Chief minister Yogi Adityanath had recently held a high-level meeting and had issued guidelines for cow protection home and saving abandoned cattle that were starving for want of fodder and care.  "The gaushalas can hold an estimated 50,000 cattle. This will help prevent cattle from straying and raiding farms," said Unnao district magistrate Devendra Pandey. UP Assembly Speaker Hridaya Narain Dixit will inaugurate the gaushalas on June 24. Pandey said that this is first such a project in the country where 100 "gaushalas "are being inaugurated in one day, constructed in just 90 days and will have maximum capacity to house 50,000 cows. While cattle was found starving for want of availability of fodder and also being abandoned by farmers after they are unproductive, Pandey and his team of officials from the veterinary department created the "bhoosa bank" (bank or storage of fodder) where farmers and people in rural areas could voluntarily donate fodder. Unnao chief veterinary officer has also created a whatsapp group of the 100 "gaushalas" spread over the 16 blocks of the district to ensure round-the-clock monitoring of the care and condition of the cattle housed there. A roaster of vets has been created and they would keep an eye on the cattle in the protection homes. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Satta Matka 2018.description: AGRA: Shyam Vohra, known as 'satta king' of the Taj city, was denied bail by district court of Agra. Vohra, who was arrested by the Agra police in July for his alleged involvement in betting on FIFA World Cup matches. Earlier, in April, Vohra was arrested by the Nodia STF from Greater Noida for placing bets on IPL matches, but he was granted bail. After Vohra’s arrest, Agra police booked him and his known associates including his son Vatsal, wife Rakhi, nephew Prateek, brother-in-law Kaushal and others for their alleged involvement in betting. On Monday, judge Anil Kumar Pundhir rejected Vohra’s bail plea, who was charged for attempt to murder, as he allegedly opened fire on policemen. Further, Vohra was charged for running illegal gambling racket, criminal conspiracy and obstructing policemen from executing their duties. Police are yet to arrest the relatives and associates of Vohra. Several years back, Vohra had gain notoriety for betting on cricket matches. In April, during IPL matches, the gambling racket run by Vohra had deposited Rs 62 lakh in 10 banks, after which police approached banks to freeze the amount. Even during the FIFA World Cup, Vohra collected huge amount of cash through betting. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Mamata Banerjee.description: VISAKHAPATNAM: Projecting TDP supremo and AP chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu as a “national leader of importance” and keeping the debate on the alternate front prospects in the ensuing elections alive, West Bengal chief minister and Trinamool Congress chief Mamata Banerjee appealed to people of AP to elect TDP again to keep the duo of Narendra Modi and Amit Shah away from power. “Who is Modi to ask about our Prime Minister candidate? We will decide who to elect our leader as there will be alternative for Modi,” she pointed out. Mamata said Naidu has done a lot for development of Andhra Pradesh. “It’s a necessity for AP people to give the power to Naidu again as he will play a key role in national politics and show a path of development to the entire country,” she added. Addressing a public meeting convened by TDP on Sunday, Mamata said Naidu is the leader to take the country forward. “Like he has done in Andhra Pradesh, Naidu can do a lot in Delhi,” she said. Coming down heavily on Modi, Mamata appealed the gathering to save the country and remove Modi (desh ko bachana hai to Modi ko hatao). “Modi claimed to be chaiwala after 2014 elections. Now he says he is chowkidar,” she added. “But chowkidar for whom? For those who looted the country. Modi had claimed that demonitisation would mitigate terrorism and stop black money, but ironically the number of terrorist attacks was the highest in the past two years. Under Modi’s regime, more number of farmers committed suicide and unemployment increased.” She added that Modi failed to explain the Pulawama incident and the Rafale deal and spurned the demand for an all-party meeting on the issues. “The nation does not want leaders like Narendra Modi and Amit Shah,” she asserted, and challenged Modi for an open debate on a national channel of his choice to discuss issues facing the country. Download The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

\u2018Tukde tukde\u2019 slogan behind UP.description: LUCKNOW: Uttar Pradesh government referred to the ‘tukde tukde’ incident in JNU when it included the clause in its ordinance on private universities in the state, mandating that the institutions will have to provide an undertaking that they would not allow any anti-national activity on their campuses. The Uttar Pradesh Private University Ordinance 2019 was passed by the state cabinet on Tuesday. Clarifying the government’s stand on seeking an undertaking from private universities that they would not allow any anti-national activity on their campuses in accordance with the ordinance, state education minister Dinesh Sharma told TOI on Wednesday that universities are centres of learning and there should be no room for such activities. While the exact parameters of what constitutes anti-national activity have not been defined, Sharma said he referred to the 2016 ‘tukde tukde’ incident in JNU to state that “such activities” would not be allowed. “Private universities should be centres of educational excellence and we will promote them in that fashion. But anti-national and anti-social activities, which weaken unity and disrupt education, will not be tolerated. In some universities, anti-national slogans have been raised like ‘Bharat tere tukde honge’ and objectionable terms used to define the nation. In UP, we are here to teach and study, not to engage in any activity that seeks to divide,” said Sharma. Adding that universities would be held liable if anything objectionable was said or done on their campuses, Sharma said that the new ordinance would act as a shield for universities. By making a university liable, he said, its administration would ensure that no anti-national activity was carried out on the campus as it would not want to be shut down. “Now they can fix their agenda and let those speaking on campus know what cannot be said or discussed. The ordinance guarantees the right to speech but will not allow any anti-national activity. One is free to criticise leaders and the country but demanding its division is not permitted,” added Sharma. Claiming that the ordinance ensured independence to universities while equipping the government to act like a chowkidaar, the education minister added that even in the distribution of honorary degrees, the government would not be recommending names but only clearing those proposed by the universities. Giving the example of former JNU president Kanhaiya Kumar, who has been charged for his involvement in the ‘tukde tukde’ incident, Sharma said that if the court was to clear his name in the case, the government would have no objection if he were to be given an honorary degree. “We have no objection to a university inviting Kumar to speak, but he cannot say the ‘tukde tukde’ kind of things there. The college cannot claim that it did not know what he or anyone would be saying,” he said. While the ordinance has been passed by the cabinet and will be presented in the upcoming assembly session scheduled to commence from July 18, Sharma remained non-committal on when it would be implemented. The 27 private universities in the state will be given one year to change their Acts in accordance with Ordinance. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

\nSpreading cheers among cops\u2019 kids.description: A cultural event Children Summer Carnival was held recently at the Reserve Police Line, Mahanagar. The event was organised by the UP Police Family Welfare Association for the wives of the Uttar Pradesh policemen. The guest of honour at the event was Neelam Singh, a lawyer and the wife of the Director General Police UP. The event exhibited paintings and drawings by children which sought much attention. The event also spread awareness regarding voting among those present.  The highlight of the event was the dance competition where children participated in good numbers. A classical dance reciatl by Unnati Giri won many hearts and a Bhangra dance performance on Punjabi songs was loved by most.  (L-R) Kalanidhi Naithani, Sarvesh Kumar Mishra and Vijay Shankar Agnihotri (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)  (L-R) Vikrant Vir (L) and Abhishek Verma and Manju Srivastava (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)  (L-R) Dr Anshita Verma (L) & Kalyani Verma and Dr Pravin Ajaz (L) and Anshu (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)  Deepti (L) and Saeeda Saira (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal) Present at the event was Minakshi Krishna Sima Modi, Dr Pravin Ajaz, Niharika Singh and Shephali Bhagat among others. — Vishnu Jaiswal In Video:Spreading cheers among cops’ kids in LucknowDownload The Times of India News App for Latest City .

BJP List 2019 Maharashtra.description: AURANGABAD/KOLHAPUR: Sitting MPs Sunil Gaikwad (Latur) and Dilip Gandhi (Ahmednagar) were denied tickets for the forthcoming Lok Sabha elections in the BJP’s first national list of candidates announced on Thursday. The list included 16 names from Maharashtra. While speculations were rife that the party would not retain Gaikwad owing to his differences with some senior BJP leaders, what came as a surprise was the ticket going to Sudhakar Shrungare, a member of the Latur zilla parishad. However, Shrungare, who is in the construction business, was the popular choice of local BJP workers. Gaikwad had won the 2014 election by a majority of over 2.5 lakh votes. Considered to be close to Union minister Nitin Gadkari, he was reportedly at loggerheads with Latur district guardian minister Sambhaji Patil-Nilangekar. The nomination of Sujay Vikhe Patil, son of senior Congress leader Radhakrishna Vikhe Patil, from Ahmednagar instead of Gandhi was a foregone conclusion ever since he joined the party last week. Sujay, a neurosurgeon by profession, will be making his entry into politics with this nomination. His late grandfather, Balasaheb Vikhe Patil, was long associated with the Congress. | Full coverage of Lok Sabha elections in MaharashtraAmong other prominent leaders from Maharashtra in the first list of candidates are Union minister Nitin Gadkari from his hometown Nagpur, state BJP chief Raosaheb Danve from Jalna, Union MoS Hansraj Ahir from Chandrapur and Union MoS for defence Subash Bhamre from Dhule. Late BJP MP Gopinath Munde’s daughter, Pritam, who was elected to Parliament with a record majority after her father’s death, has been renominated from Beed. Sitting MP from Sangli Sanjay Patil has also been renominated, putting an end to speculation over any change in constituency. Patil’s candidature was opposed by a section of BJP leaders in Sangli. However, chief minister Devendra Fadnavis is understood to have called a meeting of local party leaders and resolved the differences. The party has also given tickets to Heena Gavit from Nandurbar, Raksha Khadse from Raver, Poonam Mahajan from Mumbai North Central, Kapil Patil from Bhiwandi, Sanjay Dhotre from Akola, Ramdas Tadas from Wardha, Ashok Nete from Gadchiroli and Gopal Shetty from Mumbai North. BJP scheme: Beneficiaries to turn cadre.description: LUCKNOW: BJP is aiming to broaden its support base further by increasing party membership and is now eyeing the beneficiaries of social welfare schemes like Ujjwala, Ayushman and Saubhagya as its prospective cadres. Buoyed by its victory in recent polls in which the party reaped rich electoral dividends of Ujjwala, Ayushman and Saubhagya schemes, BJP workers would reach out to their beneficiaries, especially Dalits & OBCs, during membership drive starting from July 6, the birth anniversary of Bharatiya Jana Sangh founder, Shyama Prasad Mukherjee till August 11 and urge them to join the party. The drive is starting at a crucial time and gains significance as SP and BSP have severed their tie-up for forthcoming assembly byelections for 12 seats due later in the year. “The party believes that the beneficiaries invariably voted for us in large numbers and it is high time to include them as members,” said UP BJP general secretary, Govind Narayan Shukla. The idea, party sources said, was mooted at the party’s central committee meeting in New Delhi, which was attended by national convener of membership drive and former MP CM Shivraj Singh Chauhan. Over 1.12 crore households in UP got free gas connections under Ujjwala, while 74 lakh households benefited from Saubhagya free electricity connection. Similarly, 1.18 crore people were covered under Ayushman Bharat scheme in UP. At present, BJP has 1.8 crore party members in UP. The party has also classified polling booths on the basis of its vote percentage in recent elections. The booths where it got less votes than opposition have been classified as C grade and put on top priority along with those having more Jatav and Yadav voters during the drive. “We will try to convince voters who apparently did not vote for us,” said Shukla, and added that a meeting of regional in-charges would be held on June 22 in Lucknow and would be attended by Chauhan. The party would also announce a dedicated toll free number on which people can call to register as BJP members. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

15 dead, 36 injured in two road accident.description: SAMBHAL/FATEHPUR: At least 15 people lost their lives and 36 others sustained injuries in two separate accidents in the state, police said on Wednesday. Seven people were killed and 25 injured when a bus collided with a truck in Fatehpur on Wednesday morning, they said. Additional superintendent of police Pooja Yadav said the accident took place at the Bilari-Kaunh Modh under the Chaandpur police station area. "In the collision of a private bus with a truck, at least seven persons lost their lives, while 25 other sustained injuries. The injured have been hospitalised for treatment," Yadav said, adding that the identity of the victims is being ascertained. Police officials suspect that the toll might go up. The bus was going from Fatehpur to Jahanabad when the accident occurred. In another accident that took place late Tuesday night, at least eight people were killed and 11 others injured when their vehicle collided with a mini-goods carrier on the Moradabad-Agra National Highway in Sambhal, the officials said. Superintendent of police (Sambhal) Yamuna Prasad said on Wednesday that the victims were returning home after attending a wedding when the accident took place near Lehrawan village in the district. The injured were hospitalised and the bodies sent for postmortem, the SP added. Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath expressed grief over the loss of lives and conveyed his condolence to the family members of the bereaved, a statement issued by the UP government in Lucknow said. The chief minister has directed officials to ensure that the injured persons get adequate treatment, it added. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Kullu road accident.description: MANALI: At least 44 people have died and 29 sustained injured on Thursday when a bus fell into a gorge in Himachal's Kullu district. Kullu superintendent of police (SP) Shalini Agnihotri said several women and kids were among the injured. The vehicle had started its journey from the Banjar bus stand around 4pm and covered barely 2km when it met with an accident. The driver apparently lost control while negotiating a sharp turn at the Bhiyoth Mor, which has a gradient of more than 75 degrees. Eyewitnesses said the bus veered off the road to scrape the mountain face before hurtling down the gorge. Local residents and police personnel faced difficulty locating and extricating the bodies from the mangled mass of metal. Parts of the vehicle were strewn over a wide swathe of the bottom of the gorge. Between 2009 and 2018, Himachal Pradesh recorded 30,993 road accidents in which 11,561 people were killed and 53,909 injured. This year alone, as many as 430 people died in 1,168 road accidents in the state till May 31. UP government working for one community:.description: LUCKNOW: The Babri Masjid Action Committee (BMAC) held a meeting in Lucknow on Thursday and said Uttar Pradesh government considers itself to be working for only one particular religion and goes against the Constitution and its own written submissions in court when its ministers give anti-Babri Masjid statements. Briefing the media later, BMAC said deputy chief minister Keshav Prasad Maurya and Vishwa Hindu Parishad leaders made comments against the ongoing judicial process in Ramjanmabhoomi-Babri Masjid title suit. “In 1950, in a written statement in court, the UP government had accepted that Babri Masjid has been in use since several years for the purpose of offering namaz, and that no puja has been held in its premises by Hindus. The current government is not working in tandem with this statement,” read the press statement released later. “It appears as if the state government considers it to be the government of people of a specific religion. This is unconstitutional,” it added. Deputy CM Keshav Prasad Maurya had recently said in Ayodhya that the government will bring in a law to build Ram temple if the issue is not resolved through talks or by court. “Prime Minister Modi said in December that government will not interfere till court’s decision, so these statements are of no value,” said BMAC convener, Zafaryab Jilani. “If at all the government goes ahead and brings an ordinance on Ayodhya dispute, we will challenge it in court to demand that status quo is maintained,” added Jilani. 50 unauthorised shops hog artery, LDA bl.description: LUCKNOW: Unauthorised commercial establishments in the heart of Gomtinagar have been causing frequent traffic bottlenecks, but the Lucknow Development Authority (LDA) has turned a blind eye to the problem. At least 50 residential properties on a 2km stretch between Husadia crossing and Captain Manoj Pandey crossing host commercial centres, including coaching cradles, restaurants, garment stores and shops dealing in electrical and electronic equipment. The high footfall of customers, coupled with no designated parking lot, translates into haphazard parking which in turn triggers snarls on the artery. Chief engineer of LDA Indu Shekhar Singh said the area was both residential and commercial, but admitted that for commercial activities, a no-objection certificate was mandatory. “The NOC is issued by LDA only if fire safety and parking norms are met,” Singh said, conceding that the 50-odd establishments were in all likelihood illegal. Executive engineer Rahul Srivastava too admitted that several shops between the two traffic intersections had not been approved by the LDA, primarily because of lack of parking space outside buildings that house them. On why no action had been taken against the offenders, the LDA officials maintained that a crackdown would be launched soon. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Narendra Modi.description: RANCHI: Appealing to people to take yoga to all sections of society, Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Friday said yoga is above everything, as he performed various asanas with around 40,000 enthusiasts at the Prabhat Tara ground here to mark the fifth International Day of Yoga. Modi also urged people to make yoga an integral part of life. International Yoga Day 2019: PM urges country to embrace Yoga"We should make efforts to take yoga from cities to villages and tribal areas. Yoga is above religion, caste, colour, gender and region, it is above everything," he told the gathering. Yoga is ancient and modern. It is constant and evolving. For centuries, the essence of Yoga has remained the same… https://t.co/isvMOUTrn8— PMO India (@PMOIndia) 1561080804000The main event for the yoga day was held at the Jharkhand capital. Best pictures from International Yoga Day 2019"It (yoga) is constant and evolving for centuries. The essence of yoga has been stable and remained the same -- healthy body, stable mind, spirit of oneness. Yoga has provided a perfect blend of knowledge, karma and bhakti," the prime minister said. Events to mark the day are being held across the globe and in India, several of them are being led by Union ministers, including Amit Shah and Rajnath Singh. Modi also said the government has been working to make yoga a pillar of preventive healthcare. Follow live updates: International Yoga DayThe main event for the yoga day was held at the Jharkhand capital. Amit Shah credits PM for taking yoga to the world"It (yoga) is constant and evolving for centuries. The essence of yoga has been stable and remained the same -- healthy body, stable mind, spirit of oneness. Yoga has provided a perfect blend of knowledge, karma and bhakti," the prime minister said. Events to mark the day are being held across the globe and in India, several of them are being led by Union ministers, including Amit Shah and Rajnath Singh. Modi also said the government has been working to make yoga a pillar of preventive healthcare. Expressing concern that young people are becoming vulnerable to heart ailments, Modi said, "Yoga can play a huge role in tackling the issue and hence, this year's theme is 'Yoga for Heart'." "It is painful to read about alcoholism, substance abuse, diabetes and other things, adding yoga offers a solution to these problems," he added. He stressed that for yoga to become popular, infrastructure for it must be strengthened and said the government was working towards it. "Peace and harmony are related to yoga. People across the world must practice it," Modi said. The prime minister had arrived in Ranchi on Thursday night. On his way out of the venue, Modi shook hands with several participants, including school children, who reached out to the prime minister over barricades. The International Day of Yoga is being celebrated annually on June 21 since 2015. Maharashtra Lok Sabha Constituencies.description: MUMBAI: Maharashtra, which has 48 parliamentary constituencies, will go to polls in four phases, starting April 11. In 2009 and 2014, Lok Sabha elections were held in three phases in Maharashtra On April 11, seven constituencies in Maharashtra’s Vidarbha region will go to polls - Nagpur, Wardha, Yavatmal-Washim, and the naxal-affected areas of Gadchiroli and Chandrapur. In the second phase on April 18, 10 constituencies - including three constituencies in Vidarbha, six in Marathwada and Solapur in western Maharashtra - go to elections. The third phase, on April 23, of polling will be held in Pune, Baramati, Jalgaon, Jalna, Aurangabad, Raigad and Ratnagiri-Sindhudurg, Sangli, Satara and Kolhapur. In the final phase on April 29, all six constituencies in Mumbai, Thane, Kalyan, Palghar and Bhiwandi will go to polls among the total 17 seats in the state. KEY CONSTITUENCIESAmong the key constituencies are Baramati and Nagpur featuring high-profile candidates such as Supriya Sule and Nitin Gadkari. Then there is Ahmednagar from where Sujay Vikhe Patil, son of senior Congress leader Radhakrishna Vikhe Patil, is contesting. Other important constituencies are Jalna, Chandrapur, Dhule, Beed, Sangli, Mumbai North Central, Mumbai North and Baramati.    CONSTITUENCIES CONTENDERS   Chandrapur Union MoS Hansraj Ahir (BJP); Suresh Dhanorkar (Congress)   Baramati Kanchan Kul (BJP); Supriya Sule (Congress)   Jalna State BJP chief Raosaheb Danve BJP; Vilas Keshavrao Autade (Congress)   Akola Sanjay Dhotre (BJP); Hidayat Patel (Congress)   Bhiwandi Kapil Patil(BJP); Suresh Kashinath Taware (Congress)    Nagpur Union minister Nitin Gadkari (BJP)   Ahmednagar Sujay Vikhe Patil (BJP)   Dhule Union MoS for defence Subash Bhamre (BJP)    Beed Late BJP MP Gopinath Munde’s daughter Pritam (BJP); Bajrang Sonawane (NCP)   Sangli Sitting MP Sanjay Patil (BJP)    Mumbai North Central Poonam Mahajan (BJP)    Aurangabad Subhash Zambad (Congress)   Gadchiroli Ashok Nete (BJP)   Mumbai North Gopal Shetty (BJP)    Download The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

Tejashwi Yadav.description: PATNA/ BHAGALPUR: RJD chief Lalu Prasad’s younger son and leader of opposition in Bihar legislative assembly Tejashwi Prasad Yadav kicked off the Lok Sabha election campaign on Monday by addressing public meetings at Gaya, Banka and Bhagalpur in support of the Mahagathbandhan candidates. Close aides of Tejashwi said he is expected to address around 200 election meetings across the state over the next two months. “Tejashwi is the face of RJD and the star campaigner of Mahagathbandhan. He will be canvassing for candidates of all the Mahagathbandhan constituents — RJD, Congress, RLSP, HAM(S) and VIP. Thus, he will be addressing three to four election meetings every day,” Tejashwi’s political adviser Sanjay Yadav told TOI on Monday. Canvassing for RJD candidate Shailesh Kumar alias Bulo Mandal from Bhagalpur, Tejashwi came down heavily on NDA governments at the Centre and in state. He accused PM Narendra Modi of making false promises and propaganda to win the 2014 general election. “It won’t be repeated in the ensuing Lok Sabha elections,” Tejashwi said while raising questions about employment scenario and issues of Vijay Malaya, Nirav Modi, Mehul Chowksi and others who fled the country after swindling money from banks in India. Criticizing Nitish for snapping ties with RJD in 2017, Tejashwi said there was acute shortage of fertilizers, while the health services were also in a poor state. He accused deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi of protecting those involved in the multi-crore Srijan scam in Bhagalpur and some other districts. Urging the audience to vote for the RJD candidate, Tejashwi said the Bhagalpur voters had showed a mirror to Modi by voting for RJD in 2014. “They should do the same this election as the NDA government stands exposed,” he said. Political observers feel Tejashwi has become a good orator, especially after coming out of power in July 2017 when CM Nitish Kumar snapped ties with RJD-led Mahagathbandhan and rejoined BJP-led NDA. “Though not as good as his father in terms of having a rustic touch, Tejashwi is a good orator in terms of eloquence,” said DM Diwakar, political observer and professor at AN Sinha Institute of Social Studies. Infant dies as 2 government hospitals in.description: BAREILLY: Callousness of staff at two government hospitals in Bareilly cost a five-day-old infant her life. The family of the girl born prematurely kept running with the baby in their arms for over three hours between the two government hospitals as both of them kept referring her to each other but neither let her in. The poor infant, who had difficulty in breathing all this while, died three hours later, her family still in the hospital campus trying to get her admitted. In a similar case, a pregnant woman who had heart problem had allegedly died after these two hospitals kept referring her to each other on June 4. Taking cognizance of the incident, chief minister Yogi Adityanath later suspended the chief medical superintendent (CMS) of the district combined hospital while departmental proceedings were ordered against the CMS of the other hospital. Juvinder Pal, a resident of Gokulpur village, and his wife Preeti had their first baby, Urvashi, born prematurely at a private hospital in Aliganj under Aonla sub-division of Bareilly district last week. As baby was weak and had breathing trouble, Pal along with his mother-in-law Sushma Devi took her to the district hospital on Wednesday. When Pal finally got to see a doctor at the OPD, he referred the child to the sick newborn care unit (SNCU) of the district women’s hospital that is housed in the same campus. When Pal reached the SNCU, a doctor there wrote on Pal’s OPD slip, a copy of which is with TOI, “Bed is not available. Kindly admit your side.” “We kept running between these two government hospitals for more than three hours. When we were later coming out of the women’s hospital, Urvashi died in the arms of my mother-in-law. If my daughter had got treatment, she would have survived,” said Pal, who later gave a complaint of negligence at Kotwali police station against the staff of both the hospitals. No FIR had been filed till the filing of this report. Later when reporters reached the hospitals, an argument took place between the CMS of the women’s hospital and head nurse of combined district hospital’s pediatric ward. The superintendents of both the hospitals blamed each other. Later, chief minister Yogi Adityanath suspended district combined hospital CMS Dr KS Gupta for negligence of duty and ordered departmental proceeding against women’s hospital CMS Dr Alka Sharma. Additional director (health) Dr Pramila Gaur said, “I have sent two joint directors on Wednesday evening to both the hospitals to probe the matter and submit a report.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Yogi Adityanath.description: VARANASI: Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath slammed Congress president Rahul Gandhi for suddenly showing concern for the poor and asked why he didn’t ensure a minimum income scheme for them during Congress-led UPA regime when his mother Sonia Gandhi acted as ‘super prime minister’ and had a say in everything. Targeting Congress announcement of minimum income scheme for poor on coming to power, Yogi said, “Congress led UPA was in power in Centre from 2004 to 2014. Everybody knows how Rahul and his mother (Sonia Gandhi) were influential in UPA regime. However, in UPA’s 10-year regime Congress never showed the kind of sympathy for poor, unemployed, farmers and women of country like it is showing now for Pakistan.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

Pakistani spy lured 98 targets with bots.description: KANPUR/LUCKNOW: The Pakistani spy who went by the Facebook nickname 'Sejal Kapoor' managed to hack into the computer systems of more than 98 officials from various defence forces and organisations, including the Indian Army, Air Force, Navy, paramilitary forces and state police personnel in Rajasthan, MP, Punjab and UP between 2015 and 2018.  She "trapped" her targets by showing her videos and pictures with the help of a software malware released from a third-party server hosted in a West Asian country.  She was involved in the case related to the leak of classified data on BrahMos missile in 2018.  TOI has accessed her chats and the details of the malware called 'Whisper' used by her. Malware is an abbreviated form of 'malicious software' that is specifically designed to gain access to or damage a computer, usually without the knowledge of the owner .  Sejal's FB account had cropped up following the arrest of BrahMos senior systems missile projects engineer Nishant Agarwal by the UP anti-terrorism squad (ATS) and military intelligence (MI) for passing on classified information about the project to Pakistan spy agency ISI.  Sleuths in UP Police and MI have now unearthed more than five dozen chats of this female spy. "Well install whisper n check your desktop icon, open it and send me the code, lets talk there" the Pak spy agent says in one of the chats. "Waiting dude? Installed? After installing u will see Whisper icon on ur desktop. Just send me the code, then we will good to go. just unzip it. n click install. it's a chat app dude In UK, we all use that (sic)" she adds. "Nope, its restricted. Its getting restrictd. Whenever am trying to install it." an Indian offiical replies.  Besides 'Whisper', another spy application used by Sejal that has come to the fore is called 'Gravity Rat'.  Both work on stealth mode and have "self-aware" detection techniques which make them extremely difficult to be recognised by anti-malware programmes installed in computers.  "It's a malicious communication app. It uses a malware command. A hacker can use as many as 25 internet addresses to mask her identity," said a top intelligence official, closely monitoring the probe.  "Instantly, after getting downloaded, the malware first prompts the user to key in a code. It's to ensure that the app is not a virus or malware. Immediately after that, it scans all latest attachments sent from the computer in emails or downloads. It then scans all files with photographs, databses of MS Word and MS Excel, by first verifying their encryption keys and then opening their passwords," said a senior intelligence official. Sejal states in her FB profile that she's an employee of a firm called 'Growth Company' in Manchester, UK. Her chats also reveal she would "force install" Whisper on computers of officials from several organisations. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .
